awd_titl_txt: REU Site: REU Site on Ubiquitous Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award renews an exemplary REU site at the University of South Florida.   The site includes a strong research component combined with professional development opportunities for the participating undergraduate students from across the nation.  Students will have the opportunity to explore research topics related to ubiquitous sensing, which includes current topics such as fixed and mobile sensing networks, location-based services, participatory sensing, and human-centric sensing applications. Students will learn to use a variety of techniques including visualization and data processing techniques and algorithm development to visualize large amounts of data and track movements of people in real time. This site also will also explore operation of the site, including its research and professional development opportunities in a foreign country, Spain, to offer students a global perspective to computing and the impact of their work.

The is project is led by an outstanding team offering state-of-the art facilities and professional mentors to guide undergraduates in explorations of problems related to ubiquitous sensing. Ubiquitous sensing is an area of current interest that is well-suited to undergraduate research productivity.   Students will learn how to use current tools and techniques to solve those problems that have direct impact on people, particularly in the area of health care. The students will participate in research and professional development activities all designed to achieve the goals of retaining and graduating undergraduate students in computer science and engineering, recruiting students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing fields, and increasing recruitment of students into graduate programs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to provide a comprehensive research experience for undergraduate students, with the ultimate goal of preparing them for future academic and professional pursuits. With over one hundred applicants, the program was able to select and train 38 highly motivated and talented students.

Each summer, the students participated in a variety of academic activities designed to broaden their knowledge and skills. Workshops on special topics provided in-depth insights into specific areas of research, while symposiums allowed the students to showcase their work and receive feedback from their peers and mentors. Presentation competitions further helped the students to develop their public speaking and presentation skills. The educational field trips, such as visiting the Kennedy Space Center, offered a unique learning experience and gave the students a chance to see the practical applications of their studies.

The research experience was at the core of the program, with students being involved in a wide range of projects. They learned how to conduct research, communicate their findings, and collaborate effectively with others. Working with experienced professors and graduate students as their mentors, the students gained valuable insights and skills that will serve them well in their future academic and professional endeavors.

In addition to research and presentation skills, the program also emphasized the importance of finding funding sources and applying to graduate programs and fellowships. This was done through various workshops, discussions, and mentoring sessions, aimed at helping the students to take their careers to the next level.

Finally, the 10-week program culminated in a symposium where the students had the opportunity to present their work to a wider audience. This was an important step in their development as researchers and helped to build their confidence and reputation in the academic community. Several students in the program had their conference and journal papers accepted for peer-review and were able to present their work at major conferences, further demonstrating their potential as future leaders in their fields.

 


Last Modified: 02/13/2023
Modified by: Yu Sun
